THE ROTAHOME 3000 — PERSONAL ROTATING DWELLING UNIT

Patented in 1967 by Gerhard Muntz of Akron, Ohio, the RotaHome 3000 promised "full-spectrum solar exposure" via a house that rotated 360° every 24 hours on a lubricated concrete turntable. The brochure described it as "living inside a sundial." Residents reported persistent nausea, a complete inability to receive mail, and the psychological distress of waking up facing a different neighbor every morning. The turntable mechanism required 14 gallons of industrial lubricant per week, sourced from a single supplier in Bremen who went bankrupt in 1969. All 34 units built were condemned by 1972. The last known occupant, Mrs. Delia Farquhar of Parma, refused to leave and simply rotated in the dark for three additional months.

WHAT WENT WRONG: Everything except the concept, according to Muntz. "The house was perfect. It was the Earth that was the problem." — G. Muntz, deposition, 1971

cf. modern "smart home" — same hubris, more wifi, less honesty about the nausea.

"NEUROTROPOLIS: AI-OPTIMIZED URBAN LIVING FOR THE POST-HUMAN METRO"

Submitted by: UrbanMind Collective (a Large Language Model with a LinkedIn Premium account)

The Committee unanimously selected Neurotropolis, a 340-page AI-generated urban planning proposal that recommends replacing all public parks with "biometric reflection zones" and routing pedestrian traffic via real-time mood analysis. The document, which cites fourteen papers that do not exist and references a zoning law from a jurisdiction called "New Atlantis," demonstrates the precise variety of confident wrongness that this award was established to honor. The proposal's executive summary contains the phrase "human-centric post-human design" without irony. We note with particular admiration that the AI appears to have hallucinated an entire municipal government to approve its plan. Gerhard Muntz would be proud, if he weren't still in litigation.
